Hello and welcome to the 404 media
podcast where we bring you unparalleled
access to hidden worlds both online and
IRL. 404 media is a journalist founding
company and needs your support. To

respond to their best comments. Gain
access to that content at
404me.co. I'm your host, Joseph, and
with me are 404 media co-founders,
Emanuel Mayberg. Hello. And Jason
Kebler. Hello. Good to be here. Thank
you for having me.
On your own uh podcast, I nearly said
Sam's name by accident just because uh
my coffee hasn't kicked in. I was just
reading the script very straight. Let's
get straight into it. one story that
Jason wrote and then it'll relate to a
story that we haven't actually published
yet and I hope we publish it by the time
this comes out. Um, but the first one
inside a powerful database ICE uses to
identify and deport people. So, quick
context on what has happened with ICE
recently in the US for those who don't
know uh or need a primer. I mean, ICE
agents recently arrested a green card
holding student his at his interview to
become a US citizen. There was another
case where plain clothes officers picked
up a student off the street for
deportation despite the state department
finding no evidence she was linked to
anti-semitism or herass as claimed. Um,
and then the American and the El
Salvadorian presidents deflected when
they were asked who was going to return
a man who was mistakenly deported to a
foreign mega prison. Well, in El
Salvador and Trump has also called for
deporting US citizens to the country as
well. Um, that sort of all of the
context is happening everywhere. we find
a way into this story in the best way
that we know and that is by looking sort
of the technical infrastructure behind
all of this. And Jason, you wrote this
piece about a database called
investigative case management system or
ICM which serves as the core law
enforcement case management tool for ICE
um and specifically homeland security
investigations although as we discussed
it's a little bit broader than that. So
fill us in. What does this database and
more broadly a search tool do exactly?
Yeah. So, I mean, I think I I guess I'll
just caveat the whole conversation with
the discussion around immigration
enforcement and the revoking of visas
and, you know, actions against
universities and protesters and social
media searches of college students and
things like that.
Like, that's the context in which all of
this is happening. It's very difficult
unless you're an immigration expert to
keep track of everything that is
happening right now because there's like
dozens of ongoing court cases. There's,
you know, a recent Supreme Court ruling
about a Bgo Garcia who's a Maryland man
who's in the El Salvadorian mega prison.
Um, and I think like you said, the the
strategy that we have for covering this
is sort of figuring out what technical
infrastructure might be
powering these uh like the detentions
more or less like how how is ICE
identifying people who it wants to
deport and then what is the technical
infrastructure underneath that? And so
it's not like uh Donald Trump was
inaugurated in January and suddenly he
built like a very powerful surveillance
infrastructure. It's like ICE has been
doing really advanced surveillance. Uh
Customs and Border Patrol has been doing
really advanced surveillance. DHS more
broadly, which is the, you know, bigger
um department that both ICE and Customs
and Border Patrol and a few other
agencies fall underneath, have been
building up th this surveillance
apparatus, you know, since DHS was
founded after 9/11. And what we wrote
about was this database called the
investigative case management system,
which I believe was created in like
maybe 2013, 2014. like it's been around
for more than a decade, but it has
gotten more powerful over the last few
years. And what it does is it allows uh
HSI, HSIS, which is Homeland Security

HSI, there's so many acronyms, but HS

created for Homeland Security
Investigations, which is like an
investigative arm of ICE, which is
Immigration and Customs Enforcement, to
search like a bunch of different
databases that the government has. And
it's like a a data warehouse, I guess
you'd call it, where um you know,
Customs and Border Protection has dozens
and dozens of different databases. It
pulls all of them in and if you want to
search for let's say every blonde person
who is in the system it will show that
to you and then you can filter that. So
you can say like their port of entry was
you know uh at uh the San Diego border
crossing. You can say they are on a
specific type of visa for example.
There's also um filters for different
types of body marks, meaning scars or

know, they have like a scorecard
essentially determining whether uh
people who have specific types of
tattoos should be deported. And so this
is like a mechanism that we know of that
would allow for the types of pickups
that we have seen over the last few
months. Yeah.
And as you said, this has been around

internally into DHS. Yeah. Whenever
there's like, oh, we're going to start
selling location data, I think they have
to do a privacy threshold one first. And
that determines whether you need to then

you do that and it's like, oh, this is
all of the data that's going to be in
here. And is it going to impact people?
Is it going to include biometrics? And
yeah, it's like an internal process
which supposed to provide checks and
balances. So you don't have agencies
just running around buying all of the
fancy surveillance tech they could they
that they want. You know, there's some
sort of measure there. Yeah. Yeah. they
need to determine like whether it's
constitutional or make an argument as to
why the this technology is needed. So,
we'll talk more about that in a second,
but basically I had a source who showed
us different parts of this database uh
and sort of how it works. And so, we
were able to see the types of categories
of information that can be filtered by.
Um, and to be clear, it's hundreds of
different different characteristics,
including like biographical information,
but then also again like port of entry,
uh, where the US government believes
this person may live, uh, you know,
automated license plate reader data. So,
if they have a car registered to them,

like where they were last spotted,
things like that. Um, I'm just going to

it says 404 media saw a recent version

according to hundreds of different
categories which include things like

includes like refugee, border crossing

alien uh student visa, things like that.
Uh, and then it also includes quote
unique physical characteristics,
examples, scars, marks, tattoos,

employment, driver's license status,
bankruptcy filings, and hundreds more.
And then I had a source, the original

a database that has quote tables upon
tables of data that can be used to build

you can
imagine wanting like the Trump

specific country uh who have a specific

there's there's different ways that you

make it like really really powerful.
Yeah. And the data isn't really being

do they have access? Like it it seems

said it's really important that we do
know which parts of ICE have access to
this and exactly how they are
identifying people
because the fundamental like underlying
bedrock of privacy within the government
is if you interact with one part of the
government for one purpose that data
sharing across agencies is like a really
big potential privacy violation. And
soon after we reported this or actually
the morning that we published this um
the IRS announced that it would be
sharing data with ICE. And
so like that's a perfect example where
you have people who are paying taxes and
they're paying taxes under this idea
that they're like contributing to

know they're they're interacting with
this like civilian part of the

information with a law enforcement uh

it's I mean security investigations they
do everything. Exactly. They do. I think
that they fashion themselves as like we
do really like we're catching like
cartels and we're catching like really
big-time drug traffickers and things
like that. Um, and then they can like
refer a case to ERO, which is
enforcement and removal operations. But
the privacy impact assessments say that
enforcement and removal operations also
has access to this database, but perhaps
under a little bit more limited basis.
But then also government lawyers have
access to it. And it seems like over the
last few years more and more parts of
the government have gotten access to
this database. And the database has
gotten more powerful as more agencies

course the privacy impact assessments

And of course it'd be very interesting

sort of not knowing exactly what it

and you know this was built under either

here we are like 20 years later and one

to pull information from people who are

one of the potential privacy impacts is

that's what the experts I spoke to told

Um, but yeah, there's like quite a lot

Uh, forgive me if the headline has

and enforcement
prioritization, self-deportation
tracking and immigration life cycle

to get some people to do. And then
another one said, quote, "Modification

populations." Um, and again, I'm still

They are helping them at least that is

I think that's important to note for
